04
W h a t  d o e s  " A r t i f i c i a l  I n t e l l i g e n c e "  a c t u a l l y  m e a n ?
“Artificial” = Made by humans, not natural
“Intelligence” = The ability to think, learn, and solve problems
“Combined” = AI is the capability of machines (computers, robots) to imitate
intelligent human behavior and perform tasks that usually require human
thinking.
Example: Just like your calculator can do math (which
requires human intelligence), AI can recognize faces,
understand language, or make decisions.

How do machines learn to be "intelligent"?
06
Machines learn through experience and examples, not by being programmed with every rule:
“Machines don’t become intelligent suddenly.
 They learn slowly, just like humans.”
“First, we show them lots of examples — images,
text, videos, numbers.”
“The machine tries to guess the right answer.”
“When it’s wrong, we correct it.”
“Over time, it starts making fewer mistakes — that’s
learning.”
“After repeating this thousands or millions of times,
 it starts looking… intelligent.”

AI vs Traditional Programming
07
Traditional Software AI Software
• Follows fixed rules
• Does exactly what it is told
• Output never changes
• No learning from mistakes
• Learns from examples
• Improves with experience
• Adapts to users & data
• Gets better over time
“Traditional software works like a
calculator. We give it exact rules, and it
follows them perfectly.”
“AI software works differently.
 We don’t give it rules — we give it
examples.”
“That’s why Google Maps becomes better over time,
 but a calculator never does.”

AI, Machine Learning & Deep Learning :
06
Artificial Intelligence (AI) ⟶  Machines that show human-like intelligence
Thinking • Learning • Deciding • Recognizing patterns
“Artificial Intelligence, or AI, is the big umbrella.”
“Any machine that can learn, make decisions, or
 recognize patterns like humans — we call it AI.”
“Face unlock, recommendations, voice assistants —
all are AI.”

AI, Machine Learning & Deep Learning :
06
N o w  l e t ’ s  z o o m  i n s i d e  A I  a n d  s e e  h o w  i t  a c t u a l l y  l e a r n s .

How AI Learns: ML & Deep Learning
06
Machine Learning (ML) →  Teaching machines using data
Deep Learning (DL) →  Learning using brain-like layers (neurons)
“Machine Learning is a part of AI.”
“Instead of writing rules, we give data
 and the machine learns from examples.”
“Deep Learning is a special type of Machine Learning.”
“It uses layers of neurons, inspired by the human brain,
 which is why it works so well for images, voice, and language.”

AI is not one thing — it’s many tools working quietly.

06
AI on Your Phone = A Kitchen of Smart Tools  Different tools →  Different AI jobs
Think of your phone like a kitchen.”
“In a kitchen, you don’t use one tool for
everything.
 You use a knife, a spoon, a pan — each for a
specific job.
“AI works the same way.
 Each AI model is a special cooking assistant.”

06
Learns what you like ---> Suggests what to watch or listen
EXAMPLE: Netflix • YouTube • Spotify
This AI watches what you click, watch, or skip.
Over time, it understands your preferences.
That’s why your feed looks different from your friend’s.

EXAMPLE: Siri • Google Assistant • Alexa
This AI converts your voice to text,
 understands your request, and gives a reply.
When you say ‘Set an alarm’, this AI is working.

AI in Different Industries 
08

How AI Is Transforming Every Industry ?  
06
Healthcare • Education • Finance • Entertainment • Transportation
“AI is not just for tech companies.”
“Every industry is using AI to solve problems
faster and smarter.”
Let’s see what AI actually does in each industry.

How AI Is Transforming Every Industry ?  
06
Healthcare • Education • Finance • Entertainment • Transportation
Let’s explore the real impact of AI across industries.

HEALTHCARE :
06
– Helps doctors Finds patterns in medical dataAI in Healthcare 🏥
Example : Disease diagnosis , Drug discovery , Radiology scan analysis

Identifying AI in Daily Life 
08

Is It AI… or Just Normal Software?
06
Some apps learn. Some apps just follow rules.
Not everything digital is AI.
Today, let’s learn how to spot AI in daily life.

THE CORE RULE: What Makes Software “Intelligent”?
06
AI = Learns and adapts
Normal Software = Follows fixed rules
“This is the golden rule.”
“If software improves with experience — it’s AI.”
“If it always behaves the same — it’s not AI.”

Introduction to LLMs (Large Language Models) 
08

WHAT IS A LANGUAGE MODEL?
06
A system that predicts the next word
A language model doesn’t understand like
humans.
It looks at words and predicts what comes next.
If I say: ‘I drink tea in the ___’, you’ll say ‘morning’.
The model does the same  but using data.

HOW A LANGUAGE MODEL WORKS ?
06
How Does It Work?
You type a sentence.
The model calculates probabilities.
It picks the most likely next word.
This repeats again and again — forming full
sentences.
Your text →  Model →  Next word

WHAT MAKES IT “LARGE”?
06
Why Is It Called “Large”?
More data More parameters More learning
“Large doesn’t mean physically big.”
“It means trained on huge amounts of text.”
“Books, websites, articles, code — everything.”
Think of it like studying:
1 book →  small knowledge
Library →  much smarter answers

WHERE YOU ALREADY SEE LLMs
06
You Already Use LLMs
Writing Translating Correcting Chatting
Examples: ChatGPT • Grammarly • Google Translate • SwiftKey
These apps all understand language.
That’s why they feel human-like.

Remember This
06
LLMs predict language using massive data
“No magic. Just patterns — at a massive scale.”

Thanks
for
watching!

   d)  The  Missing  Elements:  What  information  would  have  helped  the  AI  give  you  a  better  answer?  My  role  and  the  technicality  would've  provided  a  better  output.   Question  1.1:  MY  PROMPT:  explain  time.  
Alright,  big  question,  tiny  words.  Let’s  do  this  gently.  🙂  
Time  is  how  we  make  sense  of  change .

If  nothing  ever  changed—no  motion,  no  thoughts,  no  aging,  no  cause  and  effect—there’d  be  no  need  for  time.  But  things  do  change,  so  time  is  the  framework  we  use  to  
describe
 
before
,
 
after
,
 
and
 
how
 
long
.
 
Here  are  a  few  angles,  because  time  is  slippery:  
1.  Everyday  time  (the  human  version)  
Time  is  what  clocks  measure.  
 
Seconds,
 
minutes,
 
years.
 
 
It
 
lets
 
us
 
say:
 
●  “That  happened  earlier”  
 ●  “This  will  happen  later”  
 ●  “This  took  a  long  time”  
 
It’s  practical.  It  helps  us  meet  for  coffee  and  not  miss  deadlines.  
2.  Physical  time  (the  universe’s  version)  
In  physics,  time  is  a  dimension ,  like  space.  You  don’t  just  exist  somewhere —you  exist  somewhen .  
Wild  part:  time  isn’t  absolute.  
●  It  can  run  slower  if  you  move  very  fast.  
 ●  It  can  run  slower  near  massive  objects  (like  black  holes).  
 
So
 
two
 
people
 
can
 
experience
 
different
 
amounts
 
of
 
time
 
and
 
both
 
be
 
right.
 
 
3.  Psychological  time  (the  mind’s  version)  
This  is  the  weird  one.  
●  Five  minutes  can  feel  like  forever.  
 ●  Ten  years  can  feel  like  yesterday.  
 
Your  brain  stretches  or  compresses  time  based  on  emotion,  attention,  and  memory.  Fear  slows  it  down.  Routine  speeds  it  up.  
4.  Philosophical  time  (the  “uh  oh”  version)  
Is  time  something  that  exists …  or  just  a  way  humans  describe  reality?  
Some  ideas:  
●  Only  the  present  is  real.  
 ●  Past,  present,  and  future  all  exist  at  once.  
 ●  Time  doesn’t  flow—we  move  through  it.  
 
No  consensus.  Just  excellent  headaches.  
One  simple  sentence  
Time  is  the  measure  of  change,  experienced  differently  by  the  universe,  the  body,  and  the  mind.

5.  Arrow  of  Time  (Thermodynamics)  
Fundamental  laws  mostly  time-reversible ,  but  macroscopic  processes  aren’t.

Δ S≥0\Delta  S  \ge  0Δ S≥0  
●  Entropy  increases  →  defines  direction  of  time

TIME  —  A  PHYSICS  MAJOR’S  EXPLANATION  
(Conceptual  foundations  →  classical  →  relativistic  →  thermodynamic  →  quantum)  
 
1.  What  Do  Physicists  Mean  by  “Time”?

At  its  most  fundamental  level,  time  is  the  parameter  that  orders  events  and  allows  physical  laws  to  describe  change .  
●  Without  time,  there  is  no  motion  
 ●  No  dynamics  
 ●  No  causality  
 ●  No  evolution  of  systems  
 
In  physics,  time  is  not  defined  operationally  by  clocks  first —clocks  are  physical  systems  that  measure  time.  Instead,  time  is  the  conceptual  structure  that  allows  us  to  compare  events.  
Operational  definition  
Time  is  what  is  measured  by  a  clock ,  where  a  clock  is  any  system  undergoing  regular,  periodic  change .  
Examples:  
●  Atomic  transitions  (atomic  clocks)  
 ●  Oscillating  pendulums  (classical  clocks)  
 ●  Vibrating  crystals  (quartz  clocks)  
 
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Time  orders  events  and  enables  dynamics  
 ●  Clocks  measure  time  but  do  not  define  it  fundamentally  
 ●  Time  is  treated  differently  across  physical  theories  
 
 
2.  Time  in  Classical  (Newtonian)  Mechanics  
In  Newtonian  mechanics ,  time  has  a  very  specific  and  strong  assumption:  
Time  is  absolute,  universal,  and  independent  of  the  observer  
Properties  
●  Same  for  all  observers  
 ●  Flows  uniformly  
 ●  Independent  of  space  
 ●  Independent  of  motion  
 
Mathematically:  
●  Time  ttt  is  a  global  parameter  
 ●  All  observers  agree  on  simultaneity  
 ●  Dynamics  are  described  as:

This  framework  works  extremely  well  for:  
●  Engineering  systems  
 ●  Low-speed  mechanics  
 ●  Macroscopic  phenomena  
 
But  it  fails  when:  
●  Velocities  approach  the  speed  of  light  
 ●  High-precision  timing  is  required  
 
 
Key  takeaways

●  Time  is  absolute  in  classical  mechanics  
 ●  All  observers  share  the  same  ttt  
 ●  Valid  only  at  low  velocities  and  weak  gravity  
 
 
3.  The  Crisis  of  Absolute  Time  
By  the  late  19th  century:  
●  Maxwell’s  equations  predicted  a  constant  speed  of  light  
 ●  Experiments  (Michelson–Morley)  showed  no  preferred  reference  frame  
 ●  Newtonian  time  could  not  reconcile  this  
 
This  led  to  Einstein’s  Special  Relativity ,  which  completely  redefined  time.  
 
4.  Time  in  Special  Relativity  (SR)  
Fundamental  idea  
Time  is  not  absolute.  
 
It
 
depends
 
on
 
the
 
observer’s
 
state
 
of
 
motion.
 
Einstein’s  two  postulates  
1.  Laws  of  physics  are  identical  in  all  inertial  frames  
 2.  Speed  of  light  ccc  is  constant  for  all  observers  
 
These  immediately  imply:  
●  Time  dilation  
 ●  Relativity  of  simultaneity  
 ●  Spacetime  unification  
 
 
Time  Dilation  
A  moving  clock  runs  slower  relative  to  a  stationary  observer.  
Δ t= γΔ t0, γ=11− v2/c2\Delta  t  =  \gamma  \Delta  t_0,  \quad  \gamma  =  \frac{1}{\sqrt{1  -  v^2/c^2}} Δ t= γΔ t0 , γ=1− v2/c2 1  
Where:  
●  Δ t0\Delta  t_0 Δ t0  =  proper  time  (measured  in  rest  frame)  
 ●  Δ t\Delta  t Δ t  =  dilated  time  
 
This  is  not  psychological —it  is  physical  and  experimentally  verified.  
Examples:  
●  Muon  decay  experiments  
 ●  Particle  accelerators  
 ●  GPS  satellite  clocks  
 
 
Relativity  of  Simultaneity  
Two  events  simultaneous  in  one  frame  may  not  be  simultaneous  in  another .

This  destroys  the  Newtonian  idea  of  a  universal  “now”.  
 
Spacetime  
Space  and  time  combine  into  a  four-dimensional  structure.  
Event:  
(t,x,y,z)(t,  x,  y,  z)(t,x,y,z)  
Invariant  spacetime  interval:  
s2=c2t2−x2−y2−z2s^2  =  c^2  t^2  -  x^2  -  y^2  -  z^2s2=c2t2−x2−y2−z2
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Time  depends  on  observer’s  velocity  
 ●  Proper  time  is  frame-invariant  
 ●  Space  and  time  are  unified  into  spacetime  
 ●  Simultaneity  is  relative  
 
 
5.  Proper  Time  —  The  Physically  Meaningful  Time  
Proper  time  τ\ tau τ  is  the  time  measured  by  a  clock  moving  with  the  object.  
d τ= dt1−v2c2d\tau  =  dt  \sqrt{1  -  \frac{v^2}{c^2}}d τ= dt1−c2v2   
Why  it  matters:  
●  It  is  Lorentz-invariant  
 ●  Used  in  relativistic  equations  of  motion  
 ●  Represents  the  “experienced”  time  along  a  worldline  
 
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Proper  time  is  the  physically  meaningful  time  
 ●  Frame-independent  
 ●  Central  to  relativistic  dynamics  
 
 
6.  Time  in  General  Relativity  (GR)  
In  General  Relativity ,  time  is  affected  not  just  by  motion,  but  by  gravity .  
Core  idea  
Mass-energy  curves  spacetime,  and  this  curvature  affects  time  flow.  
 
Gravitational  Time  Dilation  
Clocks  in  stronger  gravitational  fields  run  slower.  
Δ t= Δ t01−2GMrc2\Delta  t  =  \Delta  t_0  \sqrt{1  -  \frac{2GM}{rc^2}} Δ t= Δ t0 1−rc22GM   
Implications:

●  Time  runs  slower  near  massive  objects  
 ●  Near  black  holes,  time  dilation  becomes  extreme  
 ●  Essential  for  GPS  accuracy  
 
 
Time  as  Geometry  
●  Time  is  part  of  spacetime  geometry  
 ●  No  longer  a  background  parameter  
 ●  Dynamical  and  curved  
 
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Gravity  affects  time  
 ●  Time  is  geometrical  in  GR  
 ●  Required  for  precision  engineering  systems  (GPS)  
 
 
7.  Arrow  of  Time  and  Thermodynamics  
Most  fundamental  equations  (Newton,  Maxwell,  Schrödinger)  are  time-reversible .  
Yet  reality  clearly  isn’t.  
Why?  
 
Entropy  and  the  Second  Law  
Δ S≥0\Delta  S  \ge  0Δ S≥0  
●  Entropy  defines  the  direction  of  time  
 ●  Explains  irreversibility  
 ●  Applies  statistically,  not  microscopically  
 
Examples:  
●  Heat  flows  hot  →  cold  
 ●  Gases  mix,  never  unmix  
 ●  We  remember  the  past,  not  the  future  
 
 
Arrows  of  Time  
●  Thermodynamic  arrow  (entropy)  
 ●  Psychological  arrow  (memory)  
 ●  Cosmological  arrow  (expansion  of  universe)  
 
All  appear  aligned.  
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Fundamental  laws  are  time-symmetric  
 ●  Entropy  gives  time  its  direction  
 ●  Arrow  of  time  is  statistical,  not  fundamental

8.  Time  in  Quantum  Mechanics  
Quantum  mechanics  treats  time  very  differently  from  space .  
Schrödinger  Equation  
i ℏ ∂ ψ∂ t=H^ ψ i\hbar  \frac{\partial  \psi}{\partial  t}  =  \hat{H}\psii ℏ ∂t∂ ψ = H^ ψ  
Observations:  
●  Time  is  a  parameter ,  not  an  operator  
 ●  Position  is  an  operator;  time  is  not  
 ●  This  asymmetry  causes  deep  conceptual  problems  
 
 
Consequences  
●  No  time  observable  like  position  or  momentum  
 ●  Measurement  problem  involves  time  implicitly  
 ●  Leads  to  the  “problem  of  time”  in  quantum  gravity  
 
 
Key  takeaways  
●  Time  is  external  in  QM  
 ●  Not  quantized  like  space  
 ●  Major  obstacle  to  unifying  QM  and  GR  
 
 
9.  Time  Across  Theories  —  Unified  View  
Theory  Nature  of  Time  
Classical  Mechanics  Absolute  parameter  
Special  Relativity  Relative  coordinate  
General  Relativity  Dynamical  geometry  
Thermodynamics  Directional  via  entropy  
Quantum  Mechanics  External  parameter  
 
10.  Exam-Level  Summary  (Memorize  This)  
●  Time  orders  events  and  enables  dynamics  
 ●  Absolute  in  Newtonian  mechanics  
 ●  Relative  and  observer-dependent  in  relativity  
 ●  Curved  by  gravity  in  General  Relativity  
 ●  Direction  defined  by  entropy  increase  
 ●  Treated  as  an  external  parameter  in  quantum  mechanics

●  Answer:  Big  O  describes  how  the  run-time  or  space  requirements  of  an  algorithm  grow  as  the  amount  of  data  increases.  For  example,  $O(n)$  means  if  the  data

Q5:  How  do  you  reverse  a  linked  list  of  transaction  steps?  
●  Answer:  Use  three  pointers:  prev,  curr,  and  next.  Iterate  through  the  list,  flipping  the  curr.next  pointer  to  point  to  prev,  then  move  the  pointers  forward  one  step.
